was bubbled into the solution for 30 min to expel dissolved oxygen in the reaction system.After beginning irradiation, 2 mL of suspension were sampled at certain time intervals and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles.The products were qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatograph (FID detector, DB-WAX column) through observing and comparing the chromatographic peaks with those for the authentic methanol and ethanol standard.During the whole photoreduction process,

were found by introducing N 2 instead of CO 2 into the photocatalyst suspension under visible-light irradiation.This demonstrates that the photocatalysts and their residual intermediates do not contribute the organic products, and that CO 2 is the only source in the photoreduction process. 6 architectures with evolving morphologies.The Bi 2 MoO 6 samples were first evaluated for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol and ethanol as solar fuels under visible-light irradiation.It has been found that the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 exhibits highly efficient photocatalytic activity.After 4 hours of irradiation, the yields of methanol and ethanol were 24.8 and 18.8 mol g cat -1 respectively, higher than those obtained over previously-reported Bi 2 WO 6 hollow microspheres.This

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

whole photoreduction process, CO 2 gas was continuously bubbled through the solution at a rate of 50 mL min -1 .According to further analysis, the atomic molar ratio of Bi : Mo is approximately 2.1 : 1, which is close to the stoichiometric proportion of Bi 2 MoO 6 (2 : 1).Furthermore, the excess oxygen, as well as the carbon and nitrogen in the examined as-prepared catalysts, possibly originated from an organic contaminant andor residual PVP.
